awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Osmoregulation in Marine Dinoflagellates
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine phytoplankton live in a dynamic and variable environment. Changes in salinity, temperature and nutrients are major factors that control the growth and distribution of phytoplankton populations.  Salinity can vary significantly in coastal waters, so many coastal phytoplankton species have evolved mechanisms to quickly regulate their internal water concentration, a process known as osmoregulation. In response to decreases in salinity, the dinoflagellate, Karenia brevis, responsible for producing toxic red tides in the Gulf of Mexico, produces a rapid >10-fold increase in ladder frame polyethers (LFPs), which include the potent neurotoxins called brevetoxin.  The functional role of LFPs in K. brevis is unknown; however, the production of such large quantities suggests that there must be a critical cellular role. An interdisciplinary approach combining physiological experiments, cell imaging, next generation sequencing, and metabolomic profiling will be used to explore the relationship between gene transcription and physiological/metabolic responses. To determine if LFP production is a common mechanism for osmoregulation in dinoflagellates, similar experiments will be conducted with additional species of dinoflagellates also known to produce LFPs. Changes in LFP production in response to low salinity may explain how K. brevis and other toxin-producing dinoflagellates can thrive in coastal ecosystems. The project's outcome will provide an explanation for toxin production in 'red tide' dinoflagellates and reveal how toxic dinoflagellates, with slow growth rates now, may compete successfully in coastal environments under future conditions. 

The project's broader impacts include training and education of a post-doctoral researcher, three graduate students, and undergraduate students using state-of-the-art techniques to address questions in evolution and ecology. Results will also be utilized in a graduate Molecular Ecology course taught at TAMU providing students with hands-on experience with actual experimental data for training in this rapidly emerging field.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to understand how phytoplankton respond to environmental stress. Our specific focus was to investigate the genomic and metabolic response of Karenia brevis, the toxic dinoflagellate responsible for red tides in the Gulf of Mexico, to changes in salinity. Our research has shown that one way Karenia (Wilson strain) responds to decreases in salinity is to increase their production of the neurotoxic brevetoxins, which to bind to voltage gated sodium channels.  Additionally, we have discovered a new K. brevis strain (KbNT) that is not toxic and produces low levels or no brevetoxins.  The discovery of this new strain has provided a unique experimental tool to study the role brevetoxins play protecting the cell during salinity changes.  Using time course experiments from control and stressed cultures, we compared transcriptomes (the genes that have been “turned on”, or expressed) and metabolomes (the collection of molecules resulting from cell activities/processes).

Intellectual Merit: The transcriptomes for four K. brevis strains and 2 sister species have been assembled. Identification of ion channels and aquaporins in K. brevis suggests that the concentrations of ions and water within these cells are regulated by membrane proteins. Furthermore, voltage-gated Na+ channels in the organism may provide a binding site for brevetoxins, which supports the hypothesis that brevetoxin production may be linked to osmoacclimation. Analysis of time course experiments found that the primary significant response to salinity stress was observed in genes associated with light harvesting for photosynthesis, which is consistent with previous findings showing that brevetoxin localizes in the chloroplast.

Metabolomics experiments of the polar components showed differences between the Wilson and KbNT strains, as well as subtle trends of metabolic disruption caused by salinity stress.  Amino acids and nucleotides were elevated while sugars and fatty acids were lower in KbNT.  This was seen as an increase in compatible solutes and a decrease in energy rich compounds such as sugars and fatty acids. Other changes that were observed included lower concentrations in fatty compounds in KbNT as compared to the normal Wilson strain. 

Metabolomic profiles of the non-polar fraction detected over 5000 metabolites and there were approximately 40 compounds that varied significantly between control and stress treatments in Wilson. Unfortunately, the metabolomics experiments were found to not be repeatable and either compound breakdown over time while waiting in the LC-MS or adsorption of the compounds to the glass vials over time resulted in a linear loss of compounds over time. 

Novel compounds that were discovered include: the identification a new class of compounds named phyto-indenes (Figure 1), isolation and identification of 3 new ladder frame polyethers, a new sterol, four esters compounds and four glycolipids.

Other key findings include the discovery that Karenia papilionacea, a sister species to K. brevis, also produces brevetoxin. Genes unique to only these two brevetoxin-producing species were identified, including several that could be involved in brevetoxin biosynthesis. Transcriptomic analyses also confirmed, for the first time, that genes in the model C4 carbon fixation pathway are found in these dinoflagellates, as well as most other algal phyla.

Broader Impacts: Outcomes included (1) Training of the future STEM workforce: The project supported the education and training of 4 graduate students (2 students—one a Native American—completed PhD Dissertations; 2 completed Masters Theses) and one Post-doctoral Fellow. In addition, data generated from this project were utilized in a graduate course in Molecular Ecology; (2) Generating resources for the scientific community: i. short read data from this project are publically available in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive repository under BioProject PRJNA214017, accession IDs SRX363776, SRX363775, and SRX361898 and the reference transcriptomes can be accessed through LabArchive (DOI 10.6070/H44F1NPC, 10.6070/H40P0X0H, 10.6070/H4VX0DH6); ii. A non-toxin producing Karenia strainavailable for future studies. iii. Detection and quantification methods developed include a LC-MS MRM method to quantify 10 ladder frame polyethers including PbTx-1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 9, 10, PbTx-3 42 carboxylic acid, brevenal and brevisin, and a metabolomics method for [?? what is ?? this needs to be for a GENERAL audience—so delete this?? HRMS. iv. Synthesis of internal standards for brevetoxin LC-MS MRM methods, isolation and purification of ladder frame polyether compounds that were used as standards and producing these standards for the research community.  (3) Results were disseminated to the community in 12 publications in peer-reviewed journals and in 23 presentations given at national and international conferences.
